revisions.rev:
{{NCAATeamFootballSeason |Year=2007 |Team=Iowa Hawkeyes |Image=Iowa logo.jpg |ImageSize= |Conference=Big Ten Conference |Division= |ShortConference=Big Ten |CoachRank= |APRank= |Record=6-6 |ConfRecord=4-4 |HeadCoach=[[Kirk Ferentz]] |OffCoach=[[Ken O'Keefe]] |DefCoach=Norm Parker |OScheme= |DScheme= |StadiumArena=[[Kinnick Stadium]] |Champion= |BowlTourney= |BowlTourneyResult= |uniform=File:BigTen-Uniform-Iowa-2006-2008.png }} {{2007 Big Ten football standings}} The '''2007 Iowa Hawkeyes football team''' represented the [[University of Iowa]] during the [[2007 NCAA Division I FBS football season|2007 college football season]]. Heading into the season, several players left the team while several other players ran into criminal allegations. Following a disappointing [[2006 Iowa Hawkeyes football team|2006 season]] that included losses to [[Indiana University (Bloomington)|Indiana]], [[Northwestern University|Northwestern]] and [[University of Minnesota|Minnesota]], the team was coached by [[Kirk Ferentz]] and played their six home games at [[Kinnick Stadium]] in [[Iowa City, Iowa|Iowa City]], [[Iowa]].
== Previous season == {{main|2006 Iowa Hawkeyes football team}} [[File:Kinnick Stadium.jpg|thumb|left|Players prepare to play Montana on September 2, 2006.]] Entering 2006 ranked 16th in the [[AP Poll#College football|AP Poll]]<ref name="ESPN1">{{cite web|title = 2006 Associated Press NCAA Football Rankings - Week 1|url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/rankings?pollId=1&seasonYear=2006&weekNumber=1 |publisher = ESPN |date = |accessdate = 2007-08-23 }}</ref> and 17th in the [[Coaches Poll]],<ref name="ESPN2">{{cite web|title = 2006 USA Today NCAA Football Rankings - Week 1 |url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/rankings?pollId=2&seasonYear=2006&weekNumber=1 |publisher = ESPN |date = |accessdate = 2007-08-23 }}</ref> the Hawkeyes had high hopes for the season. Following victories over [[University of Montana|Montana]], [[Syracuse University|Syracuse]], [[Iowa State University|Iowa State]] and [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign|Illinois]], the Hawkeyes were 4-0 heading into their game with top-ranked [[Ohio State University|Ohio State]]. With tickets for the game going for [[United States Dollar|$]]500 on [[eBay]], the game was hyped as one of the biggest in Kinnick Stadium history.<ref name="ESPN3">{{cite web|title = No. 13 Iowa gears up for historic night at Kinnick Stadium |url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/preview?confId=&gameId=262732294 |publisher = ESPN |date = |accessdate = 2007-08-23 }}</ref> But [[quarterback]] [[Drew Tate]] threw 3 [[interceptions]], and the Hawkeyes lost 38â17. In total, Iowa had 4 turnovers while Ohio State had zero.<ref name="ESPN4">{{cite web|title = Heisman display: Smith tosses 4 TDs as No. 1 Ohio State rocks Iowa |url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?confId=&gameId=262732294 |publisher = ESPN |date = |accessdate = 2007-08-23 }}</ref>
Following the loss to Ohio State, Iowa proceeded to score a season-high 47 points in a victory over Purdue. But the most notable score came during the 4th quarter, when [[Adam Shada]] intercepted a [[Curtis Painter]] pass and returned it a school record 98-yards for the [[touchdown]].<ref name="ESPN5">{{cite web|title = Iowa blasts Purdue in first game since Ohio State drubbing |url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=262802294&confId=null |publisher = ESPN |date = |accessdate = 2007-08-23 }}</ref> However, Iowa's joy would not last long, as the Hawkeyes were upset by Indiana only a week later. The 31â28 win was Indiana's biggest win since a victory over 9th-ranked Ohio State in 1987.<ref name="ESPN6">{{cite web|title = Hardy reels in 3 TDs as Indiana shocks No. 15 Iowa |url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=262870084&confId=null |publisher = ESPN |date = |accessdate = 2007-08-23 }}</ref>
From there, the season unraveled, and the Hawkeyes lost four of their remaining five games en route to a 6-6 record.<ref name="ESPN7">{{cite web|title = Iowa 2006 Football Schedule/Results |url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/teamsched?teamId=2294&year=2006 |publisher = ESPN |date = |accessdate = 2007-08-23 }}</ref> However, the Hawkeyes came out against [[University of Texas|Texas]] in the [[2006 Alamo Bowl]] with renewed energy, and quickly jumped out to a two touchdown lead. Later, after three straight Texas scores, Iowa once again took the lead 21â20. But it was not enough to win the game, as Texas won 26â24 behind the record-tying performance of freshman quarterback [[Colt McCoy]].<ref name="ESPN8">{{cite web|title = McCoy ties freshman TD mark in Horns' Alamo Bowl win |url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?confId=&gameId=263642294 |publisher = ESPN |date = |accessdate = 2007-08-23 }}</ref>
== Before the season ==
On April 20, 2007, it was announced by Ferentz that two players, [[Ryan Bain]] and [[Justin Edwards (football player)|Justin Edwards]], were leaving the team. Both are planning on transferring to other schools.<ref name="HR1">{{cite web|title = Bain, Edwards leaving Iowa |url = http://iowa.rivals.com/content.asp?cid=665797 |publisher = HawkeyeReport.com |date = 2007-04-20 |accessdate = 2007-08-23 }}</ref> Bain, who had 56 career tackles, was later found guilty on charges of disorderly conduct.<ref name="Gazette1">{{cite web|title = Former UI football player found guilty of disorderly conduct |url = http://www.gazetteonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070601/SPORTS/70601009/1003/SPORTS |publisher = Cedar Rapids Gazette |date = 2007-06-01 |accessdate = 2007-08-23 }}</ref> About two months later, it was announced that [[Shonn Greene]] and [[Amari Spievey]] were no longer on the team. Greene, a junior [[running back]], had 378 rushing yards and two touchdowns in his career.<ref name="HN2">{{cite web|title = Greene, Spievey leaving Iowa |url = http://collegefootball.rivals.com/content.asp?cid=680716 |publisher = HawkeyeReport.com |date = 2007-06-06 |accessdate = 2007-08-23 }}</ref> Another month later, and it was announced that [[Lucas Cox]] and [[Marcus Wilson]] were leaving the team. Wilson, a sophomore [[defensive back]], played in all 13 games in 2006 and recorded 21 tackles and one interception.<ref name="HS1">{{cite web|title = Cox and Wilson Leave Hawkeyes |url =http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/072607aab.html |publisher = HawkeyeSports.com |date = 2007-07-26 |accessdate = 2007-08-23 }}</ref> Earlier in July, senior defensive back [[Devan Moylan]] was given an additional year of eligibility. After suffering a leg injury in the fourth game of 2006 against Illinois, he applied for a medical hardship. Prior to the 2007 season, he had 28 tackles and one interception in his career.<ref name="HS2">{{cite web|title = Moylan Granted Additional Year |url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/071007aaa.html |publisher = HawkeyeSports.com |date = 2007-07-10 |accessdate = 2007-08-23 }}</ref>
=== Criminal charges === On August 20, 2007, two Hawkeye [[wide receivers]] were arrested and charged with the unauthorized use of a [[credit card]]. [[Dominique Douglas]] and [[Anthony Bowman]], both sophomores, were suspended indefinitely by Ferentz following allegations that they bought more than $2,000 in merchandise with stolen credit cards. The crime is a [[felony]], and if convicted, the two players can face up to five years in [[prison]] along with a $7,500 fine.<ref name="ESPNCC">{{cite web|title = Iowa wideouts Douglas, Bowman suspended after arrest |url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=2983050 |publisher = ESPN |date = 2007-08-20 |accessdate = 2007-08-23 }}</ref> Another player, [[Arvell Nelson]], also experienced trouble with the law. Nelson posted a $545 bond for failure to appear in court after being charged with driving with a suspended license. He also paid a $390 fine for not having insurance.<ref name="DMR1">{{cite web|title = Backup quarterback Nelson posts bond |url = http://www.dmregister.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070822/SPORTS020502/708220401/1003/SPORTS&lead=1 |publisher = Des Moines Register |date = 2007-08-22 |accessdate = 2007-08-23 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070825163806/http://www.dmregister.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070822/SPORTS020502/708220401/1003/SPORTS&lead=1 |archivedate = August 25, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref>

===Schedule notes===
Due to the [[Big Ten]]'s rotating schedule, Iowa will not play either [[2007 Michigan Wolverines football team|Michigan]] or [[2007 Ohio State Buckeyes football team|Ohio State]] in 2007. Instead, Iowa will play [[2007 Michigan State Spartans football team|Michigan State]] and [[2007 Penn State Nittany Lions football team|Penn State]], two teams that the Hawkeyes have not played against since 2004.
Iowa's schedule was ranked as the 9th toughest (or 3rd easiest) in the Big Ten by [[SI.com]].<ref name="Big10schedule">{{cite web|title = Big Ten schedule rankings |url = http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2007/football/ncaa/06/18/schedules.bigten/2.html |publisher = SI.com |date = 2007-06-21|accessdate = 2007-07-05 }}</ref>

==Game notes== === Northern Illinois === {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road='''Hawkeyes''' |R1=0 |R2=13 |R3=3 |R4=0 |Home=Huskies |H1=0 |H2=3 |H3=0 |H4=0 }} Playing in [[Soldier Field]] in [[Chicago]], the Hawkeyes defeated the [[Northern Illinois Huskies]] 16â3. Albert Young ran for 144 yards and a touchdown as Iowa's defense kept the Huskies from scoring a touchdown. [[Damian Sims]] also made his mark by running for 110 yards. The Hawkeyes held Northern Illinois to 21 yards rushing, and [[Charles Godfrey (football player)|Charles Godfrey]] intercepted two [[Dan Nicholson]] passes. Sophomore quarterback [[Jake Christensen]] opened the season with 133 yards and one touchdown. {{-}}
=== Syracuse === [[File:Iowa vs. Syracuse 2007.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Iowa's defense lines up against Syracuse on September 9, 2007.]] {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Orange |R1=0 |R2=0 |R3=0 |R4=0 |Home='''Hawkeyes''' |H1=14 |H2=14 |H3=7 |H4=0 }} Behind a strong defensive performance, the Hawkeyes shut out the [[Syracuse Orange]] at [[Kinnick Stadium]]. Rebounding from a shaky performance against Northern Illinois, Christensen threw for 278 yards and four touchdowns, three of them to [[tight end]] [[Tony Moeaki]]. On special teams, [[Kenny Iwebema]] blocked two [[Field goal (football)|field goals]] to help preserve the worst loss for Syracuse coach [[Greg Robinson]] in his tenure with the Orange. After the game, Syracuse [[running back]] [[Curtis Brinkley]] said: {{cquote|We need to be a lot more fundamentally sound, there were a lot of missed assignments and there were a lot of people not hitting their targets. There's a little bit of everything we need to fix up.}}
The 35-point loss was Syracuse's most-lopsided since a 51â14 loss to [[Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football|Georgia Tech]] in the 2004 [[Champs Sports Bowl]]. {{-}}
=== Iowa State === {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Hawkeyes |R1=0 |R2=0 |R3=10 |R4=3 |Home='''Cyclones''' |H1=6 |H2=6 |H3=0 |H4=3 }} [[Iowa State University|Iowa State]] kicked its way to a 15-13 victory in [[Ames, Iowa|Ames]]. {{See also|Cy-Hawk Trophy}} {{-}}
=== Wisconsin === [[File:IowaHawkeyes2007AwayJersies.jpg|thumb|left|Huddle before Wisconsin game]] {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Hawkeyes |R1=0 |R2=10 |R3=0 |R4=3 |Home='''Badgers''' |H1=0 |H2=7 |H3=0 |H4=10 }} {{See also|2007 Wisconsin Badgers football team|Heartland Trophy}} Iowa's defense forced three Wisconsin turnovers, but could not hold off the Badgers' 4th quarter rally, losing 17â13. {{-}}
=== Indiana === {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road='''Hoosiers''' |R1=7 |R2=14 |R3=7 |R4=10 |Home=Hawkeyes |H1=0 |H2=7 |H3=6 |H4=7 }} Iowa was unable to contain a scoring explosion from Indiana, including three early touchdowns by Hoosier quarterback [[Kellen Lewis]]. Iowa added to its difficulties with penalties and breakdowns in pass protection. Although quarterback [[Jake Christensen]] passed for 308 yards and three touchdowns, he was sacked nine times, including four by Jammie Kirlew. The Hawkeyes also missed two field goals and an extra point. {{-}}
===Penn State=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Hawkeyes |R1=0 |R2=0 |R3=0 |R4=7 |Home='''Nittany Lions''' |H1=0 |H2=13 |H3=7 |H4=7 }} {{See also|2007 Penn State Nittany Lions football team}} Quarterback [[Jake Christensen]] was sacked twice, and the Hawkeyes were held scoreless until an interception near the Penn State end zone set up Trey Stross' 4th quarter touchdown reception in a 27â7 blowout loss on the road at Penn State. Iowa was held to eight first downs while Penn State had 26.<ref name="iowa recap">{{cite web|title=Penn State shuts down Iowa|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/yourturn/viewtopic.php?t=286754|publisher=The Sporting News|date=2007-10-06|accessdate=2007-10-06}}</ref> {{-}}
=== Illinois === {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Fighting Illini |R1=3 |R2=0 |R3=3 |R4=0 |Home='''Hawkeyes''' |H1=0 |H2=3 |H3=7 |H4=0 }} {{See also|2007 Illinois Fighting Illini football team}} Entering the game, Iowa had lost eight straight [[Big Ten Conference|Big Ten]] games, with their last win a 47â17 decision over Purdue on October 7, 2006.<ref name="losingstreak">{{cite web|title = (18) Illinois vs. Iowa|url = http://sports.yahoo.com/ncaaf/preview?gid=200710130028|publisher = Yahoo! Sports|date = |accessdate = 2007-10-18}}</ref> Illinois, however, entered the game ranked 18th in the country, and was looking to become bowl eligible with a win over the Hawkeyes.<ref name="losingstreak"/>
From the very beginning, the game was a defensive one. The Hawkeyes held Illinois [[running back]] Rashard Mendenhall to 67 yards, and slowed the nation's fifth-best rushing offense to 137 yards total.<ref name="Illinoisrecap">{{cite web|title = Iowa 10, (18) Illinois 6|url = http://sports.yahoo.com/ncaaf/recap?gid=200710130028|publisher = Yahoo! Sports|date = 2007-10-13|accessdate = 2007-10-18}}</ref> But the Illinois defense remained strong against the run, and held the Hawkeyes to a three yards per rush average.<ref name="Illinibox">{{cite web|title = Iowa 10, Illinois 6|url = http://sports.yahoo.com/ncaaf/boxscore;_ylt=Ah8RHIt8Fd36ZxkMJXatBDXyvbYF?gid=200710130028|publisher = Yahoo! Sports|date = 2007-10-13|accessdate = 2007-10-18}}</ref>
Illinois did not trail until late in the third quarter, when Iowa [[quarterback]] [[Jake Christensen]] found [[tight end]] Brandon Myers down the middle for the [[touchdown]].<ref name="Illinoisrecap"/><ref name="Illinibox"/> With the score at 10â6 in favor of the Hawkeyes, the Illini made a switch to Eddie McGee at quarterback, after starter [[Isiah Williams]] had a fumble recovered by Iowa. With McGee in, the Illini appeared to have stunned the [[Kinnick Stadium]] crowd with an 83-yard touchdown pass, but it was called back due to an Illinois penalty.<ref name="Illinoisrecap"/>
Despite the penalty, Illinois was not done. On Illinois' final drive, McGee drove the Illini down to the Iowa 12 with passes of 28 and 24 yards to Arrelious Benn. But with 1:12 left in the game, a McGee pass was [[Interception (American football)|intercepted]] at the goal line by Iowa's Brett Greenwood. The win was Iowa's first over a ranked team since 2005.<ref name="Illinoisrecap"/> {{-}}

=== Western Michigan === {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road='''Broncos''' |R1=12 |R2=7 |R3=6 |R4=3 |Home=Hawkeyes |H1=0 |H2=6 |H3=7 |H4=6 }} [[Mid-American Conference]] member [[Western Michigan]] surprised the Hawkeyes, 28-19, in [[Iowa City]]. {{See also|2007 Western Michigan Broncos football team}} {{-}}
